comments.commentBody: Great info, John; 'Terry" the terrier?...good thing she wasn't a poodle...  thinking legally, what would 'in toto' mean to the Wizard of Oz?
Another shoutout for Asta.  Who was FDR's dog?  Fala?

Yes, Fala was FDR's dog. I remember a great political cartoon of the day. FDR is at a podium speaking into a great cluster of microphones. Asta is peering up at him, thinking, "I wonder why he always calls those things 'my friends.'"

I didn't go the Asta route because I already had the T.

Most people think of TOTO as the little dog from The Wizard of Oz (1939). But if you go to IMDb, you learn that there is much more to this yappy little Cairn terrier. She was born Terry III in 1933 and died in 1945. She broke her foot and almost died in The Wizard of Oz. After that movie she changed her name to Toto. Toto appeared in over 10 Hollywood films. Her first film was Bright Eyes in 1934 with Shirley Temple. Today there is a life-sized statue of Toto at the Hollywood Forever Cemetery.

PS. I had ASTA first.

Budgets must start in the House. Plenty of progressive budgets have been suggested. For example look at the People's Budget:

http://cpc.grijalva.house.gov/index.cfm?sectionid=70
...

Our Budget Eliminates the Deficit and Raises a $31 Billion Surplus In Ten Years
Our budget protects Social Security, Medicare and Medicaid and responsibly eliminates the deficit by targeting its main drivers: the Bush Tax Cuts, the wars overseas, and the causes and effects of the recent recession.

Our Budget Puts America Back to Work & Restores America’s Competitiveness
• Trains teachers and restores schools; rebuilds roads and bridges and ensures that users help pay for them

...

Our Budget Creates a Fairer Tax System
• Ends the recently passed upper-income tax cuts and lets Bush-era tax cuts expire at the end of 2012
• Extends tax credits for the middle class, families, and students
• Creates new tax brackets that range from 45% starting at $1 million to 49% for $1 billion or more
• Implements a progressive estate tax
• Eliminates corporate welfare for oil, gas, and coal companies; closes loopholes for multinational corporations
• Enacts a financial crisis responsibility fee and a financial speculation tax on derivatives and foreign exchange

Our Budget Protects Health
• Enacts a health care public option and negotiates prescription payments with pharmaceutical companies
• Prevents any cuts to Medicare physician payments for a decade
...

At least it is a starting point! Sadly, it's the only one out there.The Senate has produced nothing for 3 years! That is nothing less than an abrogation of their Constitutional responsibility! They (both Dems and Repubs) should be ashamed. Good or bad, at least Ryan has something to start with as a reference point.

However, the problem with JUST the House or JUST the Senate producing a "plan" is that it will fail because of the NIH Syndrome....Not Invented Here. With the current breakdown in the two houses, neither side will accept the other's plan no matter what. That's why the Senate MUST produce at least something! Then, in conferences, saner heads can prevail and work out a COMPROMISE. By definition, a compromise means that neither side will get everything it wants but we, the American people, the 1%, the 99%, whatever, will perhaps start to see some light at the end of the deficit tunnel. Stop the election year posturing boys and girls.....act like adults and do your job!
Wait, Florida can ban water guns, but not handguns? Sooner or later those chickens do come home to roost.

Yes the uber wealthy pay a big portion of income taxes but less than half of the total Fed. revenues. SS payments make up a big portion , almost half , of revenue. And for years the surplus of SS payments has been borrowed to provide lower rates to said high earners. "We must bay back the debt." is the cry but noooooo you can't raise rates on the top even though they benefited big time by the borrowing.
How about the marginal rate when Republican Dwight Eisenhower was in office? 91%.

Actually, the economy was booming with much higher tax rates for the wealthiest.
Great argument, btw "Yeah... that's gonna work." I think you could have really driven the point home with an emoticon indicating sarcasm, though.

OK.. I get the fact that the looney left doesn't like this plan.
And your plan would be...??
Oh.. that's right... I recall now.. tax the heck out of the 1% (actually the .01%) and everything will come up smelling like roses.
Yeah... that's gonna work.
I am curious - is there any level of taxation that would be considered unfair for those evil 1%ers???
Maybe when they start to pay - I don't know - two-thirds of all taxes paid.. or maybe 80%... and those paying no Federal Income tax at all should rise from 50% to... what... 75% or 80% of citizens??
~ Man has an invincible inclination to allow himself to be deceived... Nietzsche

So...essentially even if it is garbage, it is a place to start? Garbage is garbage.
Btw, just wondering...what kind of health care plan does Mr. Ryan have?

Indeed, he is doing something wrong; and what he is doing with the GOP/Romneyville budget manifests the Republicans underhandedness regarding the federal budget, deficits and national debt.

To understand part of what Paul Ryan is doing wrong; and that is injurious to middle- and working-class Americans, follow these links:

and

You write: "I figure Paul D. Ryan, the Wisconsin Republican who is head of the House Budget Committee, must be doing something right."
It could be he's doing everything wrong.
Not to mention restricting voting rights. Vote Republican at your own peril!
Exactly.  Or risk losing a boatload of well-earned credibility.

read http://krugman.blogs.nytimes.com/2011/04/06/paul-ryans-multiple-unicorns/ among the many other columns by Paul Krugman as well as many others.
Mr Stewart stick to what you know best, buying/selling/investing in stocks/mutual funds. You have excellent credibility there but you have proven it is not transferable.
"Opening gambit" =cynical lowball negotiating position?

Ah, you must be speaking about the economy Bush inherited from Clinton, which he propped up with a devalued currency and huge debt from his pointless wars and tax breaks for the rich and then promptly ran into the ditch. (Just like the 'businessman' he touted himself as.)

Good thing his fellow 'businessman-turned-political hack' Romney wasn't around to help or he would have bought the country broke it apart and sold it for pieces to his corporate cronies and made himself (another) fortune.

What a tired shibboleth it is that the right wing has any clue about how to manage the economy. Except for their own grotesque enrichment, that is.

I miss the Bush years to0. Back when my 401k dropped by 40% and our children were dispatched to die in foreign lands. Ah, but you're right, if you were a member of the wealthy class, your 401k may have dropped but your share of the US income skyrocketed and your children were sent to ivy league schools instead of other countries to fight.
Oh yeh, new houses (whether you could afford them or not), cars, clothing, jewelry (financed by a little equity loan).  Those were the good ol days.  May they rest (permanently) in piece.

Liberals are the cause of this bad economy and it is going to take a conservative to fix it.
I yearn for the Bush years when we had unemployment at 4.5 %
Construction going on all over,,,,new houses..cars,,,clothing,, jewelry.
Happy faces...lots of cheap food...vacations....the good life the 2000's were.
We all know that.....it's been depressing for three years now.

OK, fair enough.  What is your proposal for entitlement reform? If you don't personally have one, what is the Democratic Party's?  It takes two to tango, and so far all I see is Mr. Ryan out on the dance floor by himself.

I disagree.  Even Paul Ryan himself said that he didn't expect it to pass this year - and he knew that what his budget plan proposes would not be acceptable. Indeed there are hard choices to make - sacrifices, yes - in an equitable way, and for all citizens.  Everyone is entitled to make a wish list - but not everyone has to take it seriously.

Ryan's plan ELIMINATES taxes on all unearned income (capital gains, interest and dividend income), referring to it as "double taxation" and a "second layer of taxation"--gotta love the wordsmithing (hello, ALEC?)...

"Elimination of Double Taxation of Savings. The current system essentially taxes savings twice: individuals pay tax on their earnings and, if they choose to invest those after-tax funds, they pay another tax on the return from their savings (i.e. interest, capital gains, or dividends). This proposal eliminates the second layer of taxation."

http://www.roadmap.republicans.budget.house.gov/Plan/

This means a reduction in the capital gains rate of 15% to 0% and therefore the wealthy would pay immensely less in taxes than they currently do.

It is a very clever way to hide such a proposal in plain sight.

So how is it again that the wealthy would be paying more under the Ryan plan? Most of their income derives from income that would shift from a 15% rate to 0% and "common sense" math says that would mean a vast reduction in their taxes.

And who needs loopholes with a 0% tax rate? The loopholes are a red herring.
Good try Barry.  You forgot that Obama has run up more debt in 3 years than Bush did in 8.

Bob, let me explain something to you.  Unemployment is the number of unemployed divided by the number of people seeking work.  Since more people have dropped out of the workforce than at any other time in our history, the denominator is at it's lowest point ever.  And if you know basic math, you would know that the lower the denominator, the lower the percent.  The only reason unemployment is lower is because more people are dropping out.  No wonder our country is in a tailspin, people can't grasp simple concepts.
Unemployment was well under 5% for almost the entire Bush presidency. Why, because he was pro business.
Withholding tax data clearly foreshadowed a miss. "Nonfarm Payrolls should fall by 377,000 (But they won’t)" 4/5/12 http://bit.ly/HhsmyN

I blame George Bush. Somehow, it must be his fault.

It can't be related to the skyrocketing energy prices, or the job-killing EPA regs. I doubt the bankruptcies among all the "green" firms with DOE loans made much of an impact, they never had many hires in the first place.

How bad does it have to get before the Times admits the Obama policies have failed?

Jobs in construction, and other types of warm-weather jobs, were started in January and February this year because the weather was mild. This would be pretty unusual from a seasonal perspective, and may skew the March numbers, because that month would be when these jobs normally pick up.

Could the author explain this statement: "Given the unusually warm winter, perhaps the seasonal adjustments that the Labor Department uses are a little off."  I'm not being glib--I really don't follow how the warm weather could lead to such an outcome.  Thanks.

Good grief. You say not to overreact, that "this is just one month’s report... Plus, bear in mind that the margin of error on all these numbers is huge."

So why bother reporting it? Dumb, dumb. No information is better than wrong information.

Since I am not an economist, I may be missing the boat here. However, as a scientist who works with lots of data day in and day out, it's important to realize that all data has limitations. As Mr. Williams suggests above, when you try to squeeze more out of the data than is really there, you might as well be trying to read meaning into chicken entrails.

Trying to discern a change in trend from one month's employment data does not really make sense from a statistical perspective. Anyone who follows this data from month to month knows that the figures are subsequently adjusted to reflect better information; these adjustments can be very significant. So why are we pretending to see a change in trend? Maybe there is one, but we sure can't conclude that based on what we know now. The wise conclusion here is that the new data is in general line with expectations. To be honest, I expect a little more from the NYT.
Maybe because with losing jobs every month under Bush,it was hard to find bright spots?

I agree, when the lamestream press is leaning left they wont see progress when the right is in charge. Whats even worse, they lean left and think its progress....when we wanting to be like Spain or Italy progress?
It is amazing how these so-called bright spots and "alternative interpretations" never showed up when George Bush was in office.

@Ross
For the same reason that traders sold off stocks in the futures market as soon as the numbers were released. It may not be rock solid information, but it's the only information out there.

I did not wonder about that, although I found it, and pretty much every word of this fine article, interesting.  What I wondered about, and found to be especially interesting, was the fact that most numbers were smaller in absolute terms.  "Another reason not to freak out is that this is only one month's data ... [but job growth could have been as low as 20,000 jobs]."

Amazingly, the economy is improving. But it doesn´t take a rocket scientist to see that it could have been a lot better had these treacherous GOP leaders co-operated. Indeed, if the electorate puts these same unsavory antagonists back in power, then shame on them!
